title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
message:
Damaged caused by corrosion.
Inspect all SPI Bus Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean/remove J6100.

Did you get the BIOS file from the forum?

title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
message: Actually I replace the BIOS with another one from the same board number of a working board. So BIOS is not the issue right? I will check everything related to the SPI Bus Termination as you said

title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
message:
That BIOS has dirty ME region, but is not a reason to avoid the boot.
Inspect for corrosion under microscope.

You can try to heat PCH area with quality flux; may have accumulated crap underneath.

title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN

Sorry my mistake this board did not have any water damaged I make confusion the behavior is as descripted above except water damage.

Measure all the resistors on the SPI BUS SERIES TERMINATION and all of them and giving the number according to the schematic

Could be bad CPU, or just a simple resistor damaged in the PCH/CPU area.

title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN

title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
message:
Could be one from 100 resistors.
No clue apart of classic tests.
Just in case, check all PECI related components.
Also check all L/C blocks  next the CPU; near the board edge (1V05 rails).

We have several posts describing how to heat BGA chips, in case of accumulated underneath crap.
Remember, you don't need to melt the balls.
180-200 degrees for 15-20 sec should be good enough; chip temp, not hot air station settings!

title: 820-00165-02 - Seems to be NO BRAIN
message:
Didn't see two Si dies on the CPU?
Guess which is which?
If you follow PCH lines in schematic, where they go?
Boardview should help better.

We discussed so many times about heating BGAs on the forum.
I gave you some temp/time values; you should use 20-30% of air flow.
As I said, the temp refers to chip, not to hot air station.
To achive 200 degrees on the board, the station must be set at 350-400 degress; depends the model and every unit has also its tollerance.
Distance hot air nozzle to board also must be considered.
You should practice with scrap boards.
Is all about practice, we all do it at "the eyes" (only one in my case).

The goal is to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath, not to melt the balls.
Once the (good quality) flux starts to boil, shouldn't increase the temp too much; don't exceed the time.

BTW, the role of the forum is to assist on the repair process.
For personal training, contact Rossmann staff...
